docs.title: SQLatte Documentation
docs.text:
Welcome to SQLatte - your friendly barista for data analytics! ☕

SQLatte transforms natural language questions into SQL queries, making database analytics accessible to everyone while maintaining enterprise-grade capabilities.

docs.title: What is SQLatte?
docs.text: SQLatte is a natural language to SQL analytics platform that combines the power of Large Language Models with your databases. Think of it as having a knowledgeable data analyst who speaks your language and understands your data.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Natural Language Queries: Ask questions in plain English, get SQL results
  • Multi-Database Support: Works with Trino, PostgreSQL, MySQL, and BigQuery
  • Multiple LLM Providers: Choose from Anthropic Claude, Google Gemini, or Vertex AI
  • Flexible Deployment: Widget-embeddable or standalone dashboard
  • Optional Complexity: Start simple, scale to enterprise features when needed
  • Scheduled Queries: Automate reports with email delivery
  • Analytics Dashboard: Track usage, insights, and query patterns
  • Runtime Prompts: Customize AI behavior through admin panel

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
// Embed SQLatte widget in your app
<div id="sqlatte-widget"></div>
<script src="sqlatte-widget.js"></script>
<script>
  SQLatte.init({
    container: 'sqlatte-widget',
    apiUrl: 'http://your-sqlatte-instance:5001'
  });
</script>

Then ask questions like: - "Show me top 10 customers by revenue this month" - "What's the trend of daily active users over the last quarter?" - "Compare sales between regions for Q4"

docs.title: The Barista Personality
docs.text: SQLatte acts like a friendly barista who: - Understands your requests naturally - Remembers your preferences - Suggests relevant insights - Makes complex queries feel simple

docs.title: Optional Complexity Philosophy
docs.text:
SQLatte grows with your needs:

Feature Basic Mode Enterprise Mode Querying ✓ Config-based ✓ Session-based auth Storage ✓ In-memory ✓ PostgreSQL persistence Automation - ✓ Scheduled queries Analytics - ✓ Full dashboard Customization - ✓ Runtime prompts

Features activate through configuration - no breaking changes, no forced complexity.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
• Quick Start

    Get SQLatte running in 5 minutes

    Installation Guide

  • Configuration

    Configure databases, LLMs, and features

    Configuration Guide

  • Embed Widgets

    Add SQLatte to your applications

    Widget Guide

  • API Reference

    REST endpoints and WebSocket API

    API Docs

docs.title: Database Providers
docs.text:
• Trino - Distributed SQL query engine
  • PostgreSQL - Advanced open-source database
  • MySQL - Popular relational database
  • BigQuery - Google Cloud data warehouse

docs.title: LLM Providers
docs.text:
• Anthropic Claude - Advanced reasoning and SQL generation
  • Google Gemini - Fast and efficient
  • Vertex AI - Enterprise Google Cloud AI

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
Business Analytics : Enable non-technical teams to query data without learning SQL

Data Exploration : Quickly explore datasets and find insights interactively

Automated Reporting : Schedule queries and email results to stakeholders

Embedded Analytics : Add natural language querying to your SaaS applications

Enterprise BI : Complement existing BI tools with conversational interface

docs.title: Community & Support
docs.text:
• GitHub: github.com/osmanuygar/sqlatte
  • Issues: Report bugs or request features
  • Discussions: Ask questions and share use cases

docs.title: License
docs.text:
SQLatte is open source. Check the main repository for license details.

Ready to brew some queries? Start with the Installation Guide! ☕

docs.title: Configuration Overview
docs.text: SQLatte uses a YAML-based configuration system that follows the "optional complexity" philosophy - start with minimal settings and add features as needed.

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
SQLatte loads configuration from config.yaml in the root directory. You can also specify a custom path:

python app.py --config /path/to/custom-config.yaml

Or use environment variable: 

export SQLATTE_CONFIG=/path/to/custom-config.yaml

docs.title: Minimal Configuration
docs.text:
The absolute minimum to get started:

database:
  provider: postgresql
  host: localhost
  database: mydb
  user: dbuser
  password: dbpass

llm:
  provider: anthropic
  api_key: sk-ant-xxxxx

This gives you basic natural language querying without any optional features.

docs.title: Full Configuration Structure
docs.text:
Here's the complete configuration structure:

app:
  host: 0.0.0.0
  port: 5001
  debug: false
  cors:
    enabled: true
    origins: ["*"]

database:
  provider: postgresql  # postgresql, mysql, trino, bigquery
  host: localhost
  port: 5432
  database: mydb
  user: dbuser
  password: dbpass
  # Provider-specific options...

llm:
  provider: anthropic  # anthropic, gemini, vertex
  api_key: your-key
  model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929
  temperature: 0.0
  max_tokens: 4096

analytics:
  enabled: true
  provider: postgresql
  host: localhost
  port: 5432
  database: sqlatte_analytics
  user: analytics_user
  password: analytics_pass

session:
  enabled: true
  secret_key: your-secret-key
  max_age: 86400

scheduling:
  enabled: true
  email:
    smtp_host: smtp.gmail.com
    smtp_port: 587
    smtp_user: your-email@gmail.com
    smtp_password: your-app-password
    from_address: sqlatte@yourcompany.com

prompts:
  system_prompt: |
    You are a helpful data analyst assistant...
  # Runtime prompts loaded from database when enabled

docs.title: App Settings
docs.text:
Controls the Flask application:

app:
  host: 0.0.0.0          # Listen address
  port: 5001             # Port number
  debug: false           # Debug mode (dev only!)
  cors:
    enabled: true        # Enable CORS
    origins: ["*"]       # Allowed origins

Learn more →

docs.title: Database Provider
docs.text:
Your data source connection:

database:
  provider: postgresql
  # Connection details...

Supports: PostgreSQL, MySQL, Trino, BigQuery

Learn more →

docs.title: LLM Provider
docs.text:
AI provider for natural language processing:

llm:
  provider: anthropic
  api_key: sk-ant-xxxxx
  model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929

Supports: Anthropic Claude, Google Gemini, Vertex AI

Learn more →

docs.title: Analytics (Optional)
docs.text:
Track queries, insights, and usage:

analytics:
  enabled: true
  provider: postgresql
  # Database connection...

Learn more →

docs.title: Session Management (Optional)
docs.text:
Enable user sessions for auth widget:

session:
  enabled: true
  secret_key: your-secret-key
  max_age: 86400  # 24 hours

Required for: Auth widget, scheduled queries per user

docs.title: Scheduling (Optional)
docs.text:
Enable automated query execution:

scheduling:
  enabled: true
  email:
    smtp_host: smtp.gmail.com
    smtp_port: 587
    # Email credentials...

Learn more →

docs.title: Runtime Prompts (Optional)
docs.text:
Customize AI behavior through admin panel:

prompts:
  system_prompt: |
    Default system prompt...

When analytics is enabled, prompts can be managed via admin UI.

Learn more →

docs.title: Development vs Production
docs.text:
DevelopmentProduction 
app:
  host: 127.0.0.1
  port: 5001
  debug: true
  cors:
    enabled: true
    origins: ["http://localhost:3000"]

database:
  provider: postgresql
  host: localhost
  # Local dev database

analytics:
  enabled: false  # Keep it simple

session:
  enabled: false  # Config-based widget only

app:
  host: 0.0.0.0
  port: 5001
  debug: false
  cors:
    enabled: true
    origins: ["https://yourapp.com"]

database:
  provider: postgresql
  host: prod-db.company.com
  # Production database

analytics:
  enabled: true
  provider: postgresql
  # Separate analytics database

session:
  enabled: true
  secret_key: ${SESSION_SECRET}  # From env var

scheduling:
  enabled: true
  # Email configuration

docs.title: Feature Progression
docs.text:
Start simple, add features incrementally:

Phase 1: Basic Querying 

database: { ... }
llm: { ... }

Phase 2: Add Analytics 

database: { ... }
llm: { ... }
analytics:
  enabled: true
  # ...

Phase 3: Add Sessions 

database: { ... }
llm: { ... }
analytics: { ... }
session:
  enabled: true
  # ...

Phase 4: Add Scheduling 

database: { ... }
llm: { ... }
analytics: { ... }
session: { ... }
scheduling:
  enabled: true
  # ...

docs.title: Environment Variable Overrides
docs.text:
Any configuration value can be overridden with environment variables:

# Database
export SQLATTE_DB_HOST=prod-db.company.com
export SQLATTE_DB_PASSWORD=secure-password

# LLM
export SQLATTE_LLM_API_KEY=sk-ant-xxxxx

# Session
export SQLATTE_SESSION_SECRET=random-secret-key

# Email
export SQLATTE_SMTP_PASSWORD=app-password

Environment variables take precedence over config.yaml.

docs.title: Configuration Validation
docs.text:
SQLatte validates configuration on startup:

# Run validation manually
python -m sqlatte.config validate

Common validation errors:

  • Missing required fields
  • Invalid provider names
  • Unreachable database
  • Invalid API keys
  • Port already in use

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text:
Credentials in Config

Never commit config.yaml with real credentials to version control!

Recommended approach:

  1. Create config.template.yaml with placeholder values
  2. Add config.yaml to .gitignore
  3. Use environment variables for secrets in production
  4. Store secrets in a secrets manager (AWS Secrets, Vault, etc.)

Example .gitignore: 

config.yaml
*.env
.env.local

Example config.template.yaml: 

database:
  provider: postgresql
  host: ${DB_HOST}
  password: ${DB_PASSWORD}  # Set via environment variable

llm:
  api_key: ${LLM_API_KEY}  # Set via environment variable

docs.title: Hot Reload
docs.text:
Some configuration changes don't require restart:

Requires Restart: - Database provider change - Port change - Analytics enable/disable - Session enable/disable

Hot Reloadable (with reload endpoint): - Runtime prompts (via admin UI) - LLM temperature/parameters - CORS settings

Use the reload endpoint: 

curl -X POST http://localhost:5001/api/admin/reload-config

docs.title: E-commerce Setup
docs.text:
database:
  provider: postgresql
  host: prod-db.company.com
  database: ecommerce_prod

analytics:
  enabled: true
  # Separate analytics DB

scheduling:
  enabled: true
  # Morning reports to team

docs.title: Multi-tenant SaaS
docs.text:
session:
  enabled: true
  # User isolation required

analytics:
  enabled: true
  # Track per-tenant usage

database:
  # Shared database with tenant_id

docs.title: Data Warehouse Queries
docs.text:
database:
  provider: bigquery
  project_id: my-project

llm:
  provider: vertex
  # Same GCP project

analytics:
  enabled: false
  # Keep it lightweight

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Database Setup: Configure your database provider →
  • LLM Setup: Configure your LLM provider →
  • Full Reference: Complete config.yaml reference →
  • Advanced Features: Enable analytics, scheduling, etc. →

docs.title: Configuration not loading
docs.text:
Check file location and permissions: 

ls -l config.yaml

docs.title: Environment variables not working
docs.text:
Verify variable names match pattern: 

env | grep SQLATTE

docs.title: Validation errors
docs.text:
Run explicit validation: 

python -m sqlatte.config validate --verbose

docs.title: Changes not taking effect
docs.text:
Some changes require restart: 

# Stop and restart
pkill -f "python app.py"
python app.py

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide will help you install and set up SQLatte on your system.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.8 or higher
  • Access to a database (Trino, PostgreSQL, MySQL, or BigQuery)
  • API key for an LLM provider (Anthropic, Gemini, or Vertex AI)

docs.title: Installation Methods
docs.text: Standard InstallationDockerDevelopment

docs.title: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/osmanuygar/sqlatte.git
cd sqlatte

docs.title: Install Dependencies
docs.text: pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Create Configuration File
docs.text:
Create a config.yaml file in the root directory:

app:
  host: 0.0.0.0
  port: 5001
  debug: false

database:
  provider: postgresql
  host: localhost
  port: 5432
  database: mydb
  user: dbuser
  password: dbpassword

llm:
  provider: anthropic
  api_key: your-api-key-here
  model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929

docs.title: Run SQLatte
docs.text:
python app.py

SQLatte will start at http://localhost:5001

docs.title: Using Docker Compose
docs.text:
Create a docker-compose.yml:

version: '3.8'

services:
  sqlatte:
    image: sqlatte:latest
    ports:
      - "5001:5001"
    volumes:
      - ./config.yaml:/app/config.yaml
    environment:
      - SQLATTE_CONFIG=/app/config.yaml

Build and run:

docker-compose up -d

See Docker Deployment for more details.

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text:
# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/osmanuygar/sqlatte.git
cd sqlatte

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # Windows: venv\Scripts\activate

# Install dependencies with dev tools
pip install -r requirements.txt
pip install -r requirements-dev.txt  # if available

# Run in debug mode
python app.py --debug

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
SQLatte supports environment variable overrides:

# Database configuration
export SQLATTE_DB_HOST=localhost
export SQLATTE_DB_PORT=5432
export SQLATTE_DB_NAME=mydb
export SQLATTE_DB_USER=dbuser
export SQLATTE_DB_PASSWORD=dbpassword

# LLM configuration
export SQLATTE_LLM_PROVIDER=anthropic
export SQLATTE_LLM_API_KEY=your-api-key
export SQLATTE_LLM_MODEL=claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929

# App configuration
export SQLATTE_HOST=0.0.0.0
export SQLATTE_PORT=5001

docs.title: Test the API
docs.text:
curl http://localhost:5001/health

Expected response: 

{
  "status": "healthy",
  "database": "connected",
  "llm": "available"
}

docs.title: Test Widget
docs.text:
Open your browser and navigate to: 

http://localhost:5001/widget.html

You should see the SQLatte widget interface.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that SQLatte is installed:

  1. Configure your database - See Database Providers
  2. Configure your LLM - See LLM Providers
  3. Try your first query - See Quick Start
  4. Enable optional features - See Configuration Overview

docs.title: Database Connection Issues
docs.text:
If you see database connection errors:

# Test database connectivity
python -c "from sqlatte.db import test_connection; test_connection()"

Check: - Database host and port are correct - User credentials are valid - Database exists and is accessible - Firewall rules allow connections

docs.title: LLM API Issues
docs.text:
If LLM queries fail:

  • Verify API key is correct
  • Check API key has sufficient credits/quota
  • Ensure model name matches provider's offerings
  • Test with a simple query first

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
If port 5001 is already in use:

# Change port in config.yaml
app:
  port: 5002

# Or use environment variable
export SQLATTE_PORT=5002

docs.title: Upgrading
docs.text:
To upgrade to the latest version:

cd sqlatte
git pull origin main
pip install -r requirements.txt --upgrade

Check the Changelog for breaking changes.

docs.title: Minimum Requirements
docs.text:
• CPU: 2 cores
  • RAM: 2 GB
  • Storage: 500 MB

docs.title: Recommended for Production
docs.text:
• CPU: 4+ cores
  • RAM: 4+ GB
  • Storage: 2+ GB (if using PostgreSQL analytics)
  • Database: Separate database server
  • Network: Low latency to database and LLM API

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
Production Deployment

Before deploying to production:

  • Use HTTPS/TLS for all connections
  • Store credentials in environment variables or secrets manager
  • Enable authentication if exposing publicly
  • Configure CORS appropriately
  • Review Security Best Practices

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you encounter issues:

  1. Check the Troubleshooting section
  2. Search GitHub Issues
  3. Create a new issue with:
    • SQLatte version
    • Python version
    • Database provider and version
    • Error messages and logs
    • Steps to reproduce

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get started with SQLatte in 5 minutes! This guide walks you through your first natural language queries.

docs.title: Step 1: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Make sure SQLatte is running:

curl http://localhost:5001/health

If you see a healthy response, you're ready to go! If not, check the Installation Guide.

docs.title: Step 2: Access the Interface
docs.text:
SQLatte provides multiple interfaces:

Widget InterfaceEmbedded WidgetDashboard (if enabled)

Open your browser to: 

http://localhost:5001/widget.html

This gives you the standalone widget interface for testing.

Add SQLatte to your HTML page:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>My App with SQLatte</title>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>Sales Dashboard</h1>

    <div id="sqlatte-widget"></div>

    <script src="http://localhost:5001/static/js/sqlatte-widget.js"></script>
    <script>
        SQLatte.init({
            container: 'sqlatte-widget',
            apiUrl: 'http://localhost:5001'
        });
    </script>
</body>
</html>

If you have analytics enabled: 

http://localhost:5001/dashboard

docs.title: Step 3: Your First Query
docs.text: Let's try some natural language queries!

docs.title: Basic Query
docs.text:
Type in the widget: 

Show me all customers

SQLatte will: 1. Convert your question to SQL 2. Execute the query 3. Display results in a table 4. Show the generated SQL

docs.title: Filter Query
docs.text:
Try adding conditions: 

Show me customers from New York who signed up this year

docs.title: Aggregate Query
docs.text:
Get some analytics: 

What's the total revenue by month for the last 6 months?

docs.title: Join Query
docs.text:
Combine tables: 

Show me top 10 products by revenue with their category names

docs.title: Step 4: Understanding Results
docs.text:
When you submit a query, SQLatte shows:

Generated SQL : The SQL query that was created from your natural language question

Results Table : Data returned from your database, with pagination if needed

Insights (optional) : AI-generated observations about the data

Actions : Save query, schedule it, or download results

docs.title: Save a Query
docs.text:
Click the Save button after running a query. Give it a name: 

Monthly Revenue Report

docs.title: Schedule a Query (if enabled)
docs.text:
If scheduling is enabled:

  1. Click Schedule after running a query
  2. Set frequency: Daily, Weekly, Monthly
  3. Choose time: 09:00
  4. Add email recipients: team@company.com
  5. Click Create Schedule

You'll receive automated reports via email!

docs.title: Understanding the Barista
docs.text:
SQLatte's "barista personality" means:

It remembers context : "Show me those customers again" works in follow-up queries

It suggests insights : "I notice revenue dropped in March - want to see why?"

It clarifies when needed : "Which table are you asking about - customers or orders?"

It stays friendly : Conversational tone instead of technical jargon

docs.title: Time-based Queries
docs.text:
Show me sales from last month
Show me daily active users for the past week
What's the trend of signups over the last quarter?

docs.title: Aggregations
docs.text:
What's the average order value by customer segment?
Count how many orders each customer has made
Sum up revenue by product category

docs.title: Rankings
docs.text:
Top 10 customers by total spend
Bottom 5 products by units sold
Most active users this week

docs.title: Comparisons
docs.text:
Compare revenue between Q1 and Q2
Show growth rate month over month
Which region has the highest conversion rate?

docs.title: Query Tips
docs.text:
Be Specific

Instead of: "Show me data"

Try: "Show me customers who made purchases in the last 30 days"

Use Time References

SQLatte understands: - "last month", "this year", "yesterday" - "past 7 days", "last quarter" - "between January and March"

Name Your Metrics

Instead of: "Calculate that thing"

Try: "Calculate total revenue", "Count active users"

Reference Table Names

If your database has multiple tables:

"Show me customers from the users table"

docs.title: Example Conversation
docs.text:
Here's a realistic conversation with SQLatte:

You: Show me our top customers

SQLatte: Here are the top 10 customers by total order value...
[Results displayed]

You: What about last month specifically?

SQLatte: Here are the top customers for last month...
[Results displayed]

You: Can you show me what they purchased?

SQLatte: Here are the purchases from those customers...
[Results displayed with joins]

You: Schedule this to run monthly and email it to me

SQLatte: I've scheduled this query to run on the 1st of each month
and email results to your@email.com

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you've run your first queries:

  1. Explore Configuration - Customize SQLatte's behavior in Configuration Guide
  2. Learn Widget Options - Embed SQLatte in your apps with Widget Guide
  3. Set Up Scheduling - Automate reports with Scheduled Queries
  4. Enable Analytics - Track usage with Analytics Dashboard
  5. Customize AI Behavior - Use Runtime Prompts

docs.title: "No tables found"
docs.text:
Your database connection might not have permissions to see tables.

Solution: Grant proper permissions or check your database configuration.

docs.title: "I don't understand that question"
docs.text:
The query might be too vague or reference unknown tables.

Solution: Be more specific about table names and columns.

docs.title: "Query timeout"
docs.text:
The generated SQL might be too complex or the database is slow.

Solution: Try narrowing your question or optimizing database indexes.

docs.title: Results look wrong
docs.text:
The AI might have misunderstood your schema.

Solution: - Check table and column names match what you asked - Review the generated SQL - Be more explicit about joins and filters

docs.title: Sample Questions by Database Type
docs.text:
E-commerceSaaS AnalyticsMarketingOperations 
Show me top selling products this month
What's the average cart value?
Which customers haven't ordered in 90 days?
Compare sales between categories
Show daily revenue for the last 30 days

How many active users do we have?
What's the churn rate this quarter?
Show signup trends over time
Which features are most used?
Calculate monthly recurring revenue

What's the conversion rate by campaign?
Show email open rates by segment
Which channels drive the most traffic?
Calculate cost per acquisition
Compare performance month over month

Show inventory levels by warehouse
Which orders are delayed?
Calculate on-time delivery rate
Show production output by shift
Identify bottlenecks in the process

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you get stuck:

  • Check the generated SQL to understand what query was created
  • Try rephrasing your question
  • Be more specific about table and column names
  • Look at the Examples for inspiration
  • Open an issue on GitHub

Happy querying! ☕
